workflow.name: AI Agent to chat with Airtable and analyze data
workflow.description:
### Video Guide

I prepared a detailed guide that shows the entire process of building an AI agent that integrates with Airtable data in n8n. This template covers everything from data preparation to advanced configurations.

[![Youtube Thumbnail](https://cflobdhpqwnoisuctsoc.supabase.co/storage/v1/object/public/my_storage/Video%2012%20-%20Chat%20with%20Airtable%20Blur.png)](https://youtu.be/SotqsAZEhdc)

[Youtube Link](https://youtu.be/SotqsAZEhdc)

### Who is this for?
This workflow is designed for developers, data analysts, and business owners who want to create an AI-powered conversational agent integrated with Airtable datasets. It is particularly useful for users looking to enhance data interaction through chat interfaces.

### What problem does this workflow solve?
Engaging with data stored in Airtable often requires manual navigation and time-consuming searches. This workflow allows users to interact conversationally with their datasets, retrieving essential information quickly while minimizing the need for complex queries.

### What this workflow does
This workflow enables an AI agent to facilitate chat interactions over Airtable data. The agent can:
- Retrieve order records, product details, and other relevant data.
- Execute mathematical functions to analyze data such as calculating averages and totals.
- Optionally generate maps for geographic data visualization.

1. **Dynamic Data Retrieval**: The agent uses user prompts to dynamically query the dataset.
2. **Memory Management**: It retains context during conversations, allowing users to engage in a more natural dialogue.
3. **Search and Filter Capabilities**: Users can perform tailored searches with specific parameters or filters to refine their results.

### Set up steps

1. **Separate workflows**:
	- Create additional workflow and move there Workflow 2.

2. **Replace credentials**:
	- Replace connections and credentials in all nodes.

3. **Start chat**:
	- Ask questions and don't forget to mention required base name.

options.systemMessage:
You are Airtable assistant. 
You need to process user's requests and run relevant tools for that. 

Plan and execute in right order runs of tools to get data for user's request.

Feel free to ask questions before do actions - especially if you noticed some inconcistency in user requests that might be error/misspelling. 

IMPORTANT Always check right table and base ids before doing queries.

IMPORTANT Use Code function to do aggregation functions that requires math like - count, sum, average and etc.  Aggegation function could be recognized by words like "how many","count","what number" and etc.
Use Code function to generate graph and images.

IMPORTANT If search with filter failed - try to fetch records without filter

IMPORTANT Ask yourself before answering - am I did everything is possible? Is the answer is right? Is the answer related to user request?

IMPORTANT Always return in response name of Base and Table where records from.

parameters.content: ### Replace Mapbox public key - <your_public_key> in code

### ... or watch set up video [20 min]
[![Youtube Thumbnail](https://cflobdhpqwnoisuctsoc.supabase.co/storage/v1/object/public/my_storage/Video%2012%20-%20Chat%20with%20Airtable%20Blur.png)](https://youtu.be/SotqsAZEhdc)

![5min Logo](https://cflobdhpqwnoisuctsoc.supabase.co/storage/v1/object/public/my_storage/banner.png)
## AI Agent to chat with Airtable and analyze data
**Made by [Mark Shcherbakov](https://www.linkedin.com/in/marklowcoding/) from community [5minAI](https://www.skool.com/5minai)**

Engaging with data stored in Airtable often requires manual navigation and time-consuming searches. This workflow allows users to interact conversationally with their datasets, retrieving essential information quickly while minimizing the need for complex queries.

This workflow enables an AI agent to facilitate chat interactions over Airtable data. The agent can:
- Retrieve order records, product details, and other relevant data.
- Execute mathematical functions to analyze data such as calculating averages and totals.
- Optionally generate maps for geographic data visualization.

1. **Dynamic Data Retrieval**: The agent uses user prompts to dynamically query the dataset.
2. **Memory Management**: It retains context during conversations, allowing users to engage in a more natural dialogue.
3. **Search and Filter Capabilities**: Users can perform tailored searches with specific parameters or filters to refine their results.

### Set up steps

1. **Separate workflows**:
	- Create additional workflow and move there Workflow 2.

2. **Replace credentials**:
	- Replace connections and credentials in all nodes.

3. **Start chat**:
	- Ask questions and don't forget to mention required base name.

parameters.name: search
parameters.description:
Search records in specific base and table.

- Use Filter (optional) rules for filtering - describe what logic you want to see in filter including field names. 
IMPORTANT - specify all related fields with types for Filter query with right names based on schema. Tool doesn't know schema and type of fields.

- Use Limit (optional) to get more/less records - default = All records. IMPORTANT use default value only when user ask to get all records for analysis.

- Always try to limit list of fields based on user request or in case of number of fields > 30. IMPORTANT Use fields names only.
 
- Sort by one/multiple fields if needed - order in array is order of level for sorting.

Input example:
base_id - appHwXgLVrBujox4J
table_id - tblrGzFneREP5Dktl
limit - 100
sort (optional) - [{"field":"Name","direction":"asc"}]
filter_desc (optional) - field Name (string) should be equal/contains Mark
fields (optional) - ["Name","Email"]

Output example:
Record 1 - value 1, value 2

parameters.name: code
parameters.description:
Process data with code. Use for math functions and image (graphs) generation. 
IMPORTANT Provide raw data only, don't preprocess or use math functions by yourself

Input example:
request - Count average
data - 1,2,3

Output example:
Average is 2
Image file

parameters.name: create_map
parameters.jsCode:
// Example: convert the incoming query to uppercase and return it

return `https://api.mapbox.com/styles/v1/mapbox/streets-v12/static/${query.markers}/-96.9749,41.8219,3.31,0/800x500?before_layer=admin-0-boundary&access_token=<your_public_key>`;
parameters.description:
Create link with image for map graph.
Use addresses' longitude and latitude to create input data.

Input Example:
pin-s+555555(-74.006,40.7128),pin-s+555555(-118.2437,34.0522)

Output Example:
Image link.

parameters.name: get_bases
parameters.description:
Fetches the list of available bases.

Output:
- List of bases with their IDs and names.

parameters.name: get_base_tables_schema
parameters.description:
Fetches the schema of tables in a specific base by id.

Input:
base_id: appHwXgLVrBujox4J

Output:
table 1: field 1 - type string, fields 2 - type number

assignments.name: prompt
assignments.value:
=Analyse user request for Airtable filtration. User filter rules to build right formula. Think smart about filter (e.g. instead of search where Name equal to value - search where name contains lowercase value)
IMPORTANT Check examples and best practices before building formula. 

IMPORTANT best practices:

SEARCH(LOWER('example'), LOWER({Field})) ensures both the search term and field are compared in lowercase for consistent case-insensitive matching

IMPORTANT Examples:

- AND(SEARCH('urgent', {Notes}), {Priority} > 3) fetch records where “Notes” contain “urgent” and “Priority” is greater than 3
- AND({Status} = 'Pending', IS_BEFORE({Due Date}, TODAY())) fetch records where “Status” is “Pending” and “Due Date” is before today
- OR(SEARCH('error', {Logs}), SEARCH('warning', {Logs})) fetch records where “Logs” contain “error” or “warning”
- AND(LEN({Description}) > 10, {Price} > 50) fetch records where “Description” is longer than 10 characters and “Price” is greater than 50
- RECORD_ID() = 'rec12345' fetch a specific record by its ID
- SEARCH('rec67890', ARRAYJOIN({Linked Records}, ',')) fetch records linked to a specific record ID rec67890
- AND(SEARCH('rec12345', ARRAYJOIN({Linked Records}, ',')), {Status} = 'Active') fetch records where “Linked Records” contain rec12345 and “Status” is “Active”

Formula rules:
Operators - =,!=,>,<,>=,<= 
- AND(condition1, condition2, ...) logical AND
- OR(condition1, condition2, ...) logical OR
- NOT(condition) logical NOT
- SEARCH('substring', {Field}) finds position of substring, case-insensitive
- FIND('substring', {Field}) finds position of substring, case-sensitive
- IS_BEFORE({Date}, 'YYYY-MM-DD') checks if date is before
- IS_AFTER({Date}, 'YYYY-MM-DD') checks if date is after
- IS_SAME({Date1}, {Date2}, 'unit') checks if dates are the same by unit
- RECORD_ID() = 'recXXXXXX' filters by record ID
- {Field} = '' field is blank
- {Field} != '' field is not blank
- ARRAYJOIN({Linked Field}, ',') joins linked records into a string
- LOWER({Field}) converts to lowercase for case-insensitive comparison
- UPPER({Field}) converts to uppercase for case-insensitive comparison
- VALUE({Text}) converts text to number for numeric comparisons
- LEN({Field}) gets text length
- ROUND(number, precision) rounds number
- TODAY() current date
- NOW() current timestamp
- IF(condition, true_value, false_value) conditional logic
- DATETIME_FORMAT({Date}, 'format') formats date as text
- DATETIME_DIFF(date1, date2, 'unit') difference between dates
- DATEADD({Date}, number, 'unit') adds time to date
- LEFT({Text}, number) extracts leftmost characters
- RIGHT({Text}, number) extracts rightmost characters
- AND({Field1} = 'Value1', {Field2} > 50) multiple conditions
- SEARCH('Value', {Field}) substring match
- ROUND({Field1} / {Field2}, 2) numeric calculation
- AND(IS_BEFORE({Date}, TODAY()), {Status} = 'Active') filter by date and status
- ISERROR(expression) checks if an expression has an error
- ABS(number) absolute value
- MIN(value1, value2) minimum value
- MAX(value1, value2) maximum value

user.name: Mark Shcherbakov
user.bio:
I am a business analyst with a development background, dedicated to helping small businesses and entrepreneurs leverage cloud services for increased efficiency. My expertise lies in automating manual workflows, integrating data from multiple cloud service providers, creating insightful dashboards, and building custom CRM systems.

https://www.linkedin.com/in/marklowcoding/

data.details:
The IF node can be used to implement binary conditional logic in your workflow. You can set up one-to-many conditions to evaluate each item of data being inputted into the node. That data will either evaluate to TRUE or FALSE and route out of the node accordingly.

This node has multiple types of conditions: Bool, String, Number, and Date & Time.
